summary.p: The Clone Intersections tool window provides you with a list of files that share source code with the current selection.
To access Clone Intersections, select Clone Intersections on the View - Other Windows menu.

section.title: Selection Context
section.p: The content of the Clone Intersections tool window depends on the current selection. If the selection can be interpreted as a file, Clone Intersections will list all files that share source code, i.e. have at least one clone class in common. This file will be called the reference file.
The selection context can be one of the following:

tr.td: If you have selected a file, Clone Intersections will use it as the reference file.
If you have selected a file, Clone Intersections will use it as the reference file.
If you have selected a type, Clone Intersections will determine the file the type is contained in and use it as the reference file.
If the document part of Visual Studio has the focus, Clone Intersections will use the active document as the reference file.

section.title: Representation
section.p: A typical representation of Clone Intersections will look like this:

The Clone Intersections tool window consists of two parts, a header and a file list. The header contains the reference file while the file list contains all other files that share source code with the reference file.
section.note: If the reference file only shares source code with itself the file list will be empty.
section.p: In the sample above FunctionInvocationExpression.cs is the reference file and shares code with six other files.

The bar charts show a graphical representation of the file content and clone distribution. The wider the bar, the more source code the file contains. Instead of displaying the content in top-down fashion, the bars are displayed left-right. That means that the first line is at the left side while the last line is at the right side. Each clone class is given a unique color.
For the sample above this provides you with the following pieces of information:

ul.li: MethodInvocationExpression.cs is the biggest file but it is not much larger than the reference file FunctionInvocationExpression.cs.
FunctionInvocationExpression.cs contains at least six clone classes.
Most clones are shared with MethodInvocationExpression.cs.

The clone class that is colored cyan is distributed across three files and is always contained in the upper part of the file. Contrast this with the purple clone class which contains clones in five files and is always contained in the lower part of a file.

section.note: Please note that it is possible that clones overlap. Therefore we said above that FunctionInvocationExpression.cs contains at least six clone classes; it is still possible that it contains more clone classes which are hidden in the chart due to overlapping.

section.title: Navigation
section.p: The Clone Intersections tool window allows you to easily open the files and navigate to the duplicated source code. For this you only have to right click the file (either the reference file or a file contained in the file list). In the context menu you see all clones contained in that file. Select the clone you want to open and click Open in Code Editor.
The file will be opened in the code editor and the cloned source code is selected.
section.note: For the reference file you can this even do quicker by just double clicking the appropriate clone in the chart. Double clicking a file in the file list will only open it in the code editor -- regardless which clone you clicked. Therefore, for files in the file list you have to use the context menu.

section.title: Hunting a Particular Clone Class
section.p: If you want to concentrate on a particular clone class you can also search all occurrences of it by right clicking the file, selecting a clone, and clicking on Find all Occurrences. This will open the Clone Results tool window that lists all files that contain the selected clone class.
